course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Philosophical Inquiry into the Modern World
course.description: This intermediate course will introduce students to basic philosophical methods and concepts in order to help them to explore the nature of philosophical inquiry and survey various important fields, problems and issues in the discipline. The change from the Aristotelian world-view, to the Copernican Revolution, and the present Darwinian Revolution, i.e., from a religious and teleological (purposive) view to a non-teleological view, is outlined in the class.

reviews.comment_teaching: ESN is a nice prof that is always willing to answer students' lengthy questions. He also explains those philosophy ideas pretty clearly. But sometimes when he explain topics that are not quite interesting (For me it is metaphysics), u might easily fall asleep in his lectures. But afterall this is a philosophy class so what can u say.
reviews.comment_grading:

Introduction to western philosophy, spending a short while on every philosopher mentioned above (even with 3 lectures on Kant, not everything is covered), the content is much more rigorous than say a HUMA1000X course, so register only if you are interested, which I am!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great!

Every lecture was clearly prepared and Dennis goes over the lecture materials in an easy to understand way, providing good examples for the more abstract concepts (i.e. him throwing his water bottle on the ground). If you are still puzzled after the lecture, he is very willing to answer, or even discuss further about the lecture contents. (I would know.)

And for those that aren't as attentive, the powerpoints are well made and one could learn everything needed from the powerpoints alone.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (30%): Given 5 questions on explaining different concepts from the philosophers discussed in class, choose 4 to answer. They test you on your understanding of the theories, instead of just memorizing, for example there would be questions asking for similarities between 2 philosophers, and you would have to compare them.

Final (30%): Same as midterm, covers all content after the midterm.

Reflection Essay (20%): Write about any philosopher covered in the class, in under 1000 words.

Participation (20%): 8 CANVAS discussion posts, write about 200 words discussing the lecture contents.

OPTIONAL THINGS: A presentation that would replace the lowest score question in the final exam, and being a commentator in those presentations would give a full mark for 2 of the CANVAS posts.

Average grade is close to a B, seems good! A+ requires a 97/100% or so, which I didn't get since I was going through some stuff and didn't have the mental to do the bonus things.
reviews.comment_workload:
For a common core course, not the lightest.

The readings (Which I think are necessary) are quite rigorous, and at points incomprehensible depending on the style of writing (Kant and Hegel are very hard to understand). Most would take 2 hours or so, and there's a new reading EVERY lecture, so that is quite a lot of time investment.

The exams are quite basic, and if you have understood the lecture clearly, it does not take much time to read through the powerpoints and memorize them.

As for the paper, since its less than 1000 words, it could be finished in a day or so, once you have selected your own topic.
